channel.title: Rap/Hip-Hop vs. Rock/Metal
channel.description:
What do you listen to and why?
I'm predominantly a metalhead, but I also listen to GOOD rap and hip-hop. Yes, I only listen to GOOD hip-hop. That means I don't always listen to songs about fucking the ho or drinking till you die. I listen to rap that actually means something.
Hell, a lot of the rock/metal groups I love (Korn, Limp Bizkit, Slipknot, and Linkin Park to name a small few), rap a whole bunch. But they rap about worthwhile topics. Not about their latest bling.
But since hip-hop and rap has gone mainstream, most artists think they can only rap in this small spectrum of sex, partying, and drinking to be successful, and the sad fact is that they are right. The current generation has been spoonfed t...his shitty new trend in every faucet of their existence, until they only enjoy this small band of music. It's a sad new trend. Now it's gotten to a point where most rap/hip-hop songs (those that are mainstream and most accessible, at least) sound exactly the same, or convey the same message. Listen to one, listen to them all...it seems the only way to listen to good hip-hop is to go with the obscure artists.
With metal and rock, you don't really have that problem. Sure, there are a few shitty exceptions that bow to the mainstream quagmire (Hollywood Undead, for one), but for the most part, rock and metal bands only care about making the best music possible with the best intended meanings. Screaming about a heartbreak or anger, or singing gently about a pleasure conveys a lot more meaning than rapping or "singing" with autotune about how drunk you get every day and how awesome it is.
EDIT: Yeah, I know there are other genres that aren't covered by the title (around 1,000,000 to be exact). If you like something that isn't rock or hip-hop, feel free to talk about that, as well.

item.title: Rap/Hip-Hop vs. Rock/Metal
item.dc:creator: k3nny1550
item.description:
Hopefully someone’s already plugged them, but Refused is an excellent band. “The Shape of Punk to Come” is one of my most listened to records, aside from Bloc Party’s “Intimacy,” the various segments of Celldweller’s “Wish Upon A Blackstar,” and Nine Inch Nails’ “The Downward Spiral.”

Personally I typically do not like rap as a general rule of thumb. Something about it just rubs me the wrong way.

Read full topic

item.title: Rap/Hip-Hop vs. Rock/Metal
item.dc:creator: Winged_One
item.description:
Well I’m a big fan of Shinoda…not a HUGE fan of Chester, but he’s alright.

But yeah, Shinoda totally wins LP for me.

EDIT: Limp Bizkit…certainly not my favorite, but there are a couple songs they made that I really like, namely Rollin’, Break Stuff, Livin’ It Up, and Take a Look Around.

I still love anything done by Slipknot and Korn, no matter you sayin’. Always have, probably always will. Even if they aren’t my absolute favorite groups, they’re still up there in my top five.

Read full topic

item.description:
meh, linkin park was definitely the best one mentioned but that doesn’t say much. first two albums + remix one werent THAT bad and i liked a lot of the songs that were predominantly singing. dude’s got a pretty distinctive voice, and i like that a lot. but after that, eh

item.title: Rap/Hip-Hop vs. Rock/Metal
item.dc:creator: bur
item.description:
Fancy Pants:

all of it. because it’s all shitty shit that 13 year olds trying to be “hardcore” listen to. it’s shit you listen to if you live in a trailer park and you’re angry about it.

don’t really know slipknot or korn, but limp bizkit’s first album is pretty good (pretty much goes downhill from there though, but the second and third are enjoyable imo), and yeah, I’ve always thought anything from linkin park I’ve heard was mediocre at best

item.title: Rap/Hip-Hop vs. Rock/Metal
item.dc:creator: Winged_One
item.description:
I was giving an example bands who mix metal and rap. I love Korn and Slipknot, but Tool and anything else touched by Maynard is still god to me.

Since we are going through different genres, why not.

Alternative, alt. metal, experimental, artistic, nu-metal, thrash metal, industrial, electronic, funk, funk metal, metalcore, etc.

EDIT: And LP’s first two albums literally changed my life back in the day. Hybrid Theory and Meteora are still really solid albums, actually.

Read full topic

item.title: Rap/Hip-Hop vs. Rock/Metal
item.dc:creator: X_Mastershot_X
item.description:
Inb4somejustinbieberfagshowsupandstartsaflamewar.

Huge metalhead/metalfag here, I love metal, rock and listen most of the other music genres too. the only rap i ever listened was eminem’s songs. And I stopped listening to him a year ago. I hate most of the rap music.

Alt Rock; industrial, power, death, heavy, viking metal… Yeah fuck this! I’ll just say i like metal & rock

Winged One:

(Korn, Limp Bizkit, Slipknot, and Linkin Park to name a small few)

Not very bad but seriously there are a lot of better groups than these ones out there. but again it’s your own taste.

item.title: Rap/Hip-Hop vs. Rock/Metal
item.dc:creator: Wombat
item.description:
I listen to everything. I’m pretty sure there’s no genre that wouldn’t include at least 1 decent track or artist. I think it’s a insult to music if you listen only one or two artist/genres during your life.

Jazz, Country, Alternative Rock, Indie, Power Metal, Nu Metal, Soul, House, Drum and bass, Funk, Classical…
[COLOR=‘Black’]I even find some of Justin Bieber’s choruses pretty catchy.
The only genre that I generally dislike is screamo and all that other scene pop-metal faggotry. But even there I can find good things, believe it or not. Also speedcore and splittercore techno. (Don’t search it up, it really is as bad as it sounds)

As for the topic, I don’t dislike either, but I find more good artists from Metal than HipHop. Though that’s maybe because I’ve listened metal/rock more during my life.

@Ramirezoid Mass music is generally disliked among the “real musicians” because there’s so big amounts of money in the business that it’s not about making music anymore, it’s just marketing and brainwashing more prepubescent fans to buy the decent music and worship the artist. (Note that this is not necessarily my opinion, just what I’ve heard millions of times.)

Read full topic
